title.narrative: LEADING FROM THE SOUTH 2 GENERAL PROGRAMME

description.narrative: Common results framework for the Leading from the South Programme. The LFS consortium has selected the following three WRGE basket indicators as the most applicable to the Leadership from the South II. These have been incorporated into the Outcome and Output Measurement Plans.OUTCOME INDICATOR 2.1 # of laws, policies and strategies blocked, adopted or improved to women’s voice, agency, leadership and representative participation in decision making processes in public, private and civic sphere OUTCOME INDICATOR 2.2 # of times that CSOs (disaggregated by women-led, youth-led or other and formal/informal) succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions on women’s voice, agency, leadership and representative participation in decision making processes in public, private and civic sphere, through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or movement building. OUTPUT INDICATOR 5.2.1 # of organizations (disaggregated by women-led, youth-led or other and formal/informal) with strengthened capacity to advance women’s rights and gender equality.

activity-date.narrative: Common results framework for the Leading from the South Programme

transaction.ref: LEADING FROM THE SOUTH 2 GENERAL PROGRAMME
Leading from the South 2- General Programme

title.narrative: Baseline study. Leading from the South Programme. FIMI

description.narrative: This document is intended as an additional support tool for defining the instruments required to arrive at a Baseline (BL) for the early stages of Phase 2 in the Leading from the South (LFS) Programme, establish the target values of its indicators, and carry out their monitoring and evaluation processes. It also serves as a first attempt at setting a Baseline for the LFS Programme implemented by the International Indigenous Women's Forum (FIMI), relying, to that end, on secondary information concerning Phase 1 of the Programme

The International Indigenous Women’s Forum, FIMI, through Indigenous Women Fund - AYNI, introduces the Leading From the South II (LFS II) Programme Annual Operating Plan (AOP) 2022 and the budget plan. This plan carries a different layout from the previous LFS work plan and aligns with FIMI Theory of Change (ToC), Strategic Plan and Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) Framework as well as LFS II programme documents and key components required by the Dutch Ministry of Foregin Affairs, (MFA). The plan consists of six components including the global context analysis and linkages with FIMI and the covid19 implication. Followed by risk analysis, AOP and activities description, forecasted substantial shifts, LFS II baseline, and budget plan for 2022.

title.narrative: AYNI's Leading from the South Annual report 2022

description.narrative: The International Indigenous Women’s Forum (FIMI) Ayni Fund — introduces the Leading from the South II (LFS II) Programme Annual Report 2021. This report consists of 7 chapters and annexes. Following introduction in Chapter 1, context analysis in Chapter 2 highlights the external and internal environmental changes that impact Indigenous Women (IW) movement and program operation. In chapter 3 and 4, the output and outcome level program progress inline with the program including Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (WRGE) basket indicators, and financial progress in summary explaining the changes are highlighted. Chapter 5 reflects on the risks and the adopted strategies for their management. LFS Theory of Change (TOC), International Aid Transparency Initiative (IATI) reporting, cross cutting issues on gender, youth, and partnership and sustainability are reflected in chapter 6 followed by good practices and lessons learnt in the last chapter 7.

title.narrative: Number of times that Indigenous Women's organisations manage to create spaces in the public and civic spheres for their demands and positions according to topic and level (gathers data on WRGE basket indicator 2.2)

description.narrative: LFS Programme aims at empowering the organisations to increase their participation in national, regional and international decision-making spaces and develop advocacy power. To this end, Indigenous Women's organisations will be positioned specific issues on the global agendas of the movement, based on the problems that women experience in their territories. This will be also facilitated by their access to and the allocation of resources for their participation in key advocacy spaces at the global level.

title.narrative: # of times that CSOs (disaggregated by type of organization and region) succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions on women’s voice, agency, leadership and representative participation in decision making processes in public, private and civic sphere, through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or movement building.

description.narrative: The LFS Programme aims at strengthening the autonomy and empowerment processes of Indigenous Women's organisations, raising their visibility and their voices at the local, regional, and international level. The implementation of a support strategy , together with regional meeting spaces and the interaction with other programmes of the Forum, favoured the strengthening of partner organisations at different levels,

Since the data was calculated based on the participation of Indigenous Women Organizations in the 2WCIW, actual values will be updated once processing mid-term and final partner’s reports. Disaggregation will be updated accordingly.During the Second World Conference of Indigenous Women, 9 AYNI´s partners including 5 regional/large level namely Continental Network of Indigenous Women of the Americas (ECMIA), Alianza de Mujeres Indígenas de Centro América y México (AMICAM), Network of Indigenous Women in Asia (NIWA), Asia Indigenous Women Network (AIWN) and African Indigenous Women’s Organization(AIWO) and 4 national/medium level namely National Indigenous Women’s Federation(NIWF), South Vihar Welfare Society for Tribal (ASHRAY), National Indigenous Disabled Women Association Nepal (NIDWAN) and BIWN (Bangladesh Indigenous Women Network) received grants as part of their institutional strengthening process. In this process, they were able to identify their own creative initiatives based on their needs prior to and during the conference. AYNI Partners organized the parallel sessions covering the issues of Land, territories and Resources, Climate Change, IW Resilience Power for Violence free life, Migration and COVID-19, Economic empowerment and so on in 2WCIW which was first from them over their lifetimes. Also, 13 IW representing 10 Asian AYNI Partners were panelists in 2WCIW’s different sessions. More than 100 (12%) IW from tentatively 30 AYNI Partners participated in 2WCIW conference as a whole and/or in different parallel sessions. IWO´s participation in the 2WCIW allowed them to strengthen internally, acquired greater project management and administration capacities and increased their leadership and participation in decision-making spaces to the enforcement of women's rights and gender equality. In this process, regional networks of Indigenous Women have come together to bring a “Global Political Declaration of Indigenous Women- that presents their priorities and recommendations as well as add the Indigenous woman’s voice on to the global statement. The collective document was presented to different organizations and stakeholders at national, regional and global level. Through capacity building and indigenous women’s meaningful participation, their participation elevated indigenous women’s self confidence and capacity in critical areas, improving their participation in decision-making processes and promoting self-confidence of their cultural and gender identities.
Africa: 1 LAC: 2 Asia: 6 Small IWO: 0 Medium/National IWO:4 Large/Regional IWO: 5
